Ask HN: How far are we from a TikTok-style app with 100% ML generated content?
text:
This idea came up on Reddit recently. [0]

I have been thinking about it ever since. Some questions I have:

Do you see this happening?

Would people use such an app, if they knew it was "AI?"

Should something like this be allowed to exist, or would it be considered something bad for society, like smoking? (I assume it would not be banned)

[0] https://old.reddit.com/r/Futurology/comments/10o07ov/at_some_point_there_will_be_a_tiktoklike_app_with/

Ask HN: Do you use Flow (JS type checker) in 2023?
text:
I am more and more thinking about switching from TS to Flow. I have always liked the strictness of Flow. The biggest disadvantage is the syntax incompatibility with TypeScript, especially declaration files.

Are you using Flow in 2023? What are your experiences with it?

Show HN: Inverse Kinematics in the Browser with Rust
text:
I built a small web app as a way to teach myself inverse kinematics/controls concepts-- and to get more familiar with Rust and Web Assembly.

My takeaways:

- Redundant Inverse Kinematics is very complex. Treating it as an optimization problem has the simplest model but is very inefficient. Jacobian methods are much faster but have their own quirks and limitations.

- Web Assembly is pretty slow actually (for my use case). Where I was seeing a 100x speedup on native Rust over js, I was only seeing a 4-6x speedup of WASM over js.

Ask HN: Improving Your Communication Skills?
text:
Hi Folks,

The ability to simplify technical concepts so that they are relevant and impactful to non-technical audiences is one of the most valuable skills to have in tech.

For some this comes naturally, but for others it needs to be strengthened like a muscle.

For those who needed to strengthen it, how did you do it?

text: Just tried this to see how well it works and I'm impressed. It took less than 30 min to set up a ticket triage system for Home Depot from the OpenAI quickstart. No need to set up intents or do anything, GPT3 labels customer inquiries with high accuracy and knows when an issue is unrelated to Home Depot support.

Ask HN: What makes a README file awesome?
text:
I recently read many thoughts on how to write a README file -- the most important part of a repo? -- and I'd love to have the opinion of the community here.

What makes a README file awesome from your point of view? What are the key elements you'd expect when reading one? Any good example?

And by 'awesome,' I mean a file that's resourceful and makes you want to contribute.

Thanks :)

Show HN: git-genie can generate commit messages for you based on the actual diff
text:
I'm developing a GPT-3 based git-assistant cli tool called git-genie, and since the latest update, it has been able to generate commit messages based on the staged changes.

The tool's primary purpose is not to replace git but to help folks learn it by generating commands from English prompts and having the option to create a detailed manpage-like explanation for them.

Show HN: Magic – automatically keep your inbox clean
text:
Magic automatically sorts away unsolicited sales emails and newsletters into a separate folder in your Gmail inbox. We're starting with two simple categories, but want to branch out to helping people better organize their inbox.

Question for the community: What frustrates you most about your inbox? What do you often miss?
